Name: YSUscape Elm & Madison Mural
Message: Student led mural project completed in an effort to improve gateway into historic neighborhood and University's campus.

Name: We Are Youngstown'
Message: Student mural project to improve blank space adjacent to art gallery in Downtown Youngstown

Name: Memories of South Avenue
Message: Mural project featuring historic businesses that were located along South Avenue. Collaboration between student group YSUscape, Taft Promise Neighborhood, and Green Youngstown.

Name: Mahoning Commons Fence Line Mural Project
Message: The mural, titled ‘Project Yo’, was designed by Random Acts Of Artists (Sharon, PA) and installed at the Western Reserve Transit Authority headquarters on Mahoning Ave. Its theme is the evolution of a city – from a downtown skyline outline to a solid skyline and then an explosion of colors and patterns – and consists of over 25,500 multi-colored chain-link fence inserts which were installed by the community. The Mahoning Commons Association served as the host organization for the project and Youngstown CityScape served as project manager. The project was funded by The Raymond John Wean Foundation’s Neighborhood SUCCESS program.

Name: Highland County Administration Building Mural
Message: The mural serves to highlight the rich historical sites throughout Highland County's cities and villages that can still be visited today.

Name: Civil War Telegraph Office
Message: Mural depicts the War Department Telegraph office during Civil War with Abraham Lincoln, the 16th president of the United States, Edwin M. Stanton, his Secretary of War and David Homer Bates, his telegraph operator. Stanton and Bates both being natives of Steubenville, OH

Name: River Reflections
Message: A 3-D mural depicting the Ohio River at Steubenville, OH with 3 boats painted to scale, as well as the Hartje Paper Mill, which in 1813 operated 6 days a week, producing 80 tons of paper daily and was largest in the U.S.

Name: Old Reliance Firehouse
Message: Depicts first Steubenville Firehouse and first steam pumper purchased for the city, which is drawn by horse and wagon.  Artist used images of local firefighters and other city residents, as well as the artist's dog, a cat and another dog in the painting.

Name: His First Deposit
Message: Depicts the Miners & Mechanics Bank on opening day, with a small boy making 'his first deposit' to George Barthold, the President of the bank.   Artist painted a miner and a mechanic in the mural because of name of bank and since the working class was the type of people for which this bank was founded.  This is Steubenville's smallest mural.

Name: Rotary Club
Message: This mural depicts Steubenville Rotary Club, showing images of actual members, as well as the founder Guy Jacobs, the first public health nurse in Jefferson County, a disabled child, representing the Club's involvement in funding handicapped children around the world, and the Club's crest.  This mural was the artist's first mural and he painted himself painting the mural into the picture.

Name: Steel Mill Memories
Message: This mural honors the steel industry and workers of the area.  The central part of the mural depicts a steel mill of the past with two 15 foot workers and a water boy.  The background shows an overhead crane in the now extinct open hearth. The plates to either side show the steel making process beginning with the mining of the coal and ending with the finished products.

Name: Stone Quarry
Message: The Stone Quarry mural gives viewers a feel for the work of men in the early days of Steubenville. There were four leading stone quarries in the area.  The artist painted faces of rock stars on the men working in the quarry including the faces of The Beatles.

Name: Steam Laundry
Message: As with River Reflections and Old Reliance Firehouse the Steam Laundry mural depicts Steubenville during the advent of the steam era.  Little is known about the laundry other than it was one of the largest employers in the city at that time.   The edifice depicted in the mural was destroyed by fire and a more modern building was then erected.

Name: Religious Beginnings
Message: This mural depicts early religious life in Steubenville featuring the first Catholic Church built in the area in 1832, the renovated church in late 1800s, the Dominican Sisters who taught at the Catholic School for over 100 years and an altar made of Carraro marble from Carraro, Italy.  The main figure in the center is St. John Neumann who lived at St. Peter's in 1841 and later became Bishop of Philadelphia and was canonized a Saint by Pope Paul VI.  Beneath him is Rev. Thomas Powers, who built the current church in 1907 and some successor pastors.

Name: Ohio River Oil Company
Message: This mural depicts a station which was built  around 1920 and was operated as a blacksmith shop and repair garage in the transition period when cars were replacing horses.  In 1929 the station was remodeled into a modern filling station and repair garage.  It was known for its 'soft water for radiators' and its very modern Ladies Lounge.

Name: 1897 Centennial Arch
Message: Called Steubenville's "Super Mural" depicting one of the four arches that spanned the city's main street and built in celebration of Steubenville's Centennial Celebration in 1897.The dimensions of this mural are 100' x 30'.  It is a 3-D mural and people have difficulty believing it is painted on a flat surface.

Name: Dean Martin
Message: This mural is a lasting tribute to Steubenville native, Dean Martin, born Dino Paul Crocetti. The central image of the mural is Martin performing, surrounded by in the upper left side by Martin with Jerry Lewis, his side kick; lower left is Martin on his TV show; at upper right is The Rat Pack with Frank Sinatra and Sammy Davis, Jr.; and lower right Martin's return to Steubenville in 1950 appearing in a parade with his wife, Jeanne and pal, Jerry Lewis.

Name: Pioneer Days
Message: The large figure in the center of this mural is of a 'pioneer' surveying the rich fertile valley where Steubenville now stands. To the left represents 'plenty' and to the right 'industry'.  The most famous and most photographed curve on the Ohio River is in the background.  The dates on the top of the arch indicate the founding of Steubenville in 1797 and the Bicentennial in 1997. You can see Jupiter and the Moon in this mural and also in the Centennial Arch Mural.

Name: Banking Pioneers
Message: This mural depicts the Union Deposit Bank, which was the first bank in the area, established in 1854. The two gentlemen in the mural are Horatio Garrett and D.J. Sinclair, who were the founders of the bank.

Name: Honor Roll Mural
Message: In 1945 an Honor Roll board with names of service men of WWII was dedicated and placed in front of the Jefferson County Court House.  It was one of the largest in the nation extending 82 feet with a 10 foot front and two 36 foot wings. In the 1960's the Honor Roll board had to be removed because of weather damage.  This mural represents the original Honor Roll board, although not all the original names appear because there had been no master list kept.

Name: Franciscan University of Steubenville
Message: The University began as the College of Steubenville in 1946 and became Franciscan University of Steubenville in 1986.This mural is divided into 6 sections surrounding the University Seal and the Poverello Medal awarded by the University annually in the middle.  The upper left depicts the downtown campus when the College was established; the upper center is St. Francis of Assisi (patron of the founding order of priests); upper right shows student life on campus; lower left study & graduating classes; lower center portrays four presidents of the University and Bishop John King Mussio, first bishop of the Diocese; and lower right is an aerial view of Franciscan's campus at its current site.

Name: Ladies Female Seminary
Message: This mural depicts the Female Seminary, a successful private school founded by Rev. C.C. Beatty in 1829, also known as Dr. Beatty Seminary.The very impressive Seminary with its beautiful grounds is shown in the background of the painting and in the foreground are the 12 members of the ONO Social Club. The painting was created from a photo in an album of a Steubenville woman whose mother is the lady leaning on the wicker chair. Also shown in the painting is the grandmother of Woodrow Wilson.

Name: Market Street Mural
Message: This mural is the first of the City of Mural's project, painted and dedicated in 1986.The mural depicts turn of the Century scene of Market Street, the main retail and government services district, first surveyed by Bazaleel Wells in 1796.  The three modes of transportation at the time are depicted as trolley, bicycle and horse and buggy. The artist painted himself in the mural with a bicycle in the lower right hand corner.

Name: Old Signs, Old Times
Message: This mural also called the "Drug Store" Mural depicts a sign for the Beall & Steel Drug Store, which was the largest drug store in Eastern Ohio at that time.  The drug store sold all the latest remedies live leeches, herbs, liniments, horse collars and much more. The man on the delivery wagon is the likeness of Sam Corabi, a Steubenville attorney who at the time of the mural's creation owned the building where the drug store had been housed and had found the old sign in the basement.

Name: Central Recreation Center
Message: This mural depicts the Central Recreation Center which served as the focal point of black community life from its inception in 1915 until 1979.  The center was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps. The gentleman shown in the mural is Dennis Palmer, Sr., the center's first director.  The penny represents the "Penny Lunches" served on a daily basis during the depression.  Various activities at the center also appear in the mural.

Name: Stanton Park
Message: This mural shows a scene of Stanton Park which was founded in 1901 by the Steubenville Tractor & Light Company. The main reason for it being established was to lure customers aboard the trolley which was the easiest way to reach the park.  The park had a swimming pool, a large carousel, small roller coaster, Ferris wheel, a dance hall and many other attractions.   There was also a lake with an island bandstand and many miles of winding trails.

Name: Steubenville's Medical Heritage
Message: This mural represents the progression of medical care in Steubenville. Depicting medical facilities over the years including a building on North 6th Street donated by J.J. Gill, owner of Acme Glass,which became The Gill Hospital in 1901, the Lacy Hotel, an old building owned by Dohrman Sinclair and donated to be used as a temporary hospital while the new Ohio Valley Hospital was being constructed, a patient's room and a nursery.
